```{r, echo = FALSE, results = "hide"}
f1 <- sample(10:99, 1) # force 1 (N)
f2 <- sample(10:99, 1) # force 2 (N)

ans <- signif(sqrt(f1^2 + f2^2), 3)

sc <- num_to_schoice(ans, delta = ans/100, format = FALSE)
sc$questions <- sprintf("%g N", signif(sc$questions, 3))
```

Question
========
Two forces act on an object. A `r f1`-N force acts at $0^\circ$ and a `r f2`-N force
acts at $90^\circ$. What is the magnitude of the equilibrant?


```{r, echo = FALSE, results = "asis"}
answerlist(sc$questions, markup = "markdown")
```


Solution
========
Perpendicular forces are added using the Pythagorean theorem. The equilibrant has
the same magnitude as the sum of the two forces.
$$F_{eq} = \sqrt{`r f1` N + `r f2` N} = `r ans` \text{ N}$$
